dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF IMAGES AND SOUNDS, (INT.HOSPITAL 0.R.)
dialogues.text: emerge from the darkness: A blast of light like an interrogation room, the flatline BEEP of an EKG machine. NURSE straddles a MAN, unconscious on the gurney. She pum his chest with all her might, her hair falling loose from the red bandana that holds it in place.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL PERSONNEL
dialogues.text: Swarm around the gurney. Faces covered, dressed in scrub suits, they look like green androids..A moment later, the SURGEON makes his entrance like-Caesar. Tufts of black ha poke through his V-neck surgical suit. NURSES and AIDS ju to his every request. He pulls the nurse from the patient chest. Voiced=over dialogue is couriterpoint to the scene. It fa in first as two women LAUGHING...The first to speak SOUND distinctly Afro-American, South Boston.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: George W. and Dick Cheney jump out of a plane. Who hits the ground first?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I dunno. Who?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Who cares? Afro-American hands pass a syringe to the surgeon who administers the lidocaine to the dying man. Nothing. Stil flatliner. The nurse in the bandana hands two paddles to Surgeon. The paddles are placed on the man's chest. A bea The man's chest arcs and falls. The American eagle tatooe on his flabby white bicep wiggles helplessiy.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, why do polish dogs have pug noses?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Why? :

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: From chasing parked cars. The surgeon rips the man's chest armpit to armpit. Someon hands him a spreader. The surgeon places the instrument o the ribs and cranks open the chest exposing the shrunken blue-grey heart. The surgeon shoves his hands into the ch and begins to massage the tiny, broken organ.

dialogues.speaker: . WOMAN
dialogues.text: What's brown and'white and looks good on a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: A pit bull. The flatline never changes. After a few beats, the surgeo removes his hand from the chest, walks away briskly. The rest of the personnel follow except for the nurse in the bandana. She stares at the room which looks like Beirut a a bombing. Pulling the spreader from the man's chest, the nurse gently covers him as she would an ailing child. Alo she begins to clean up the mess.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You know how to save a doctor from drowning?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Good. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the nurses just seen are the women we've heard tel jokes. The Afro-American’ nurse (WINNIE) is lean, dark, " The nurse in the red bandana is DENISE, early "30"s, exceptionally pretty but with eyes fresh with disappointm and an attitude tinged with sarcasm. She looks as if she just figured out that life is a great cosmic joke with a punch line. The last name on her name tag reads DEFIORE (pronounced De-fury). It fits. The women scan the back st for someone.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Where the hell are they? Okay, why do hummingbirds hum?

dialogues.speaker: WINNIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: They don't know the words.

dialogues.speaker: WINNIE
dialogues.text: That's a sorry ass joke, Denise.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Gimme a break here. What's the ETA on those bozos?

dialogues.speaker: WINNIE
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes. SOUNDS of a quickly approaching vehicle. Headlights splas the dock. A siren SOUNDS. We think it's an ambulance. It' a pizza delivery truck. Dialogue overlaps.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: A siren. What an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time. The driver of the pizza truck hops out with a large box.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA DRIVER
dialogues.text: Siren's a tease. Just for you.

dialogues.speaker: WINNIE
dialogues.text: You ‘bout as funny as a crutch. (examines the pizza) Double sausage, bacon, extra cheese. In the b.g. a real ambulance is HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: WINNIE
dialogues.text: Wait. Maybe it's goin' uptown. The ambulance SOUNDS again. Much closer. Another NURSE ap at the double doors.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER NURSE
dialogues.text: Hey campers, we got a black male, shotgun to the gut.

dialogues.speaker: WINNIE
dialogues.text: Damn. You know the other night I had five gunshot wounds, three stabbings...

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: ---and a partridge in a pear tree. A fresh-faced, nervous INTERN steps onto a dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Is he old enough to shave?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: He's not even old enough to fuck. Winnie laughs out loud, snorts. The ambulance SCREAMS aro the corner stops on a dime at the back of the loading doc a Boston police car on its tail. Paramedics pull the blee MAN from the ambulance, his stomach blown open by a doubl barrel blast....we HEAR..."BP eighty over forty... pulse forty as the gurney pushes inside the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's suddenly, weirdly silent except for the gurney wheel squeaking wildly over the tile floor. Denise, Winnie, the paramedic and even the cops exchange looks, wait for the intern to bark orders.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: (to the intern) What'll it be, Ace? We gotta fix this guy so Boston's finest can interrogate him to death. The intern mumbles, exhausted, panicked. The man's chest gurgles. :

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Ten cc's of lidocaine.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Lidocaine? That was the sucker's lung collapsing. The intern mumbles incoherently. We HEAR, "BP sixty over forty..." It's now or never, so Denise takes over.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get a tube in his chest.... Denise continues to bark orders over the gurney as it rol down the hall to the OR...we HEAR..."large bore IV..." The intern shakes, confused and alone. After a few beats, when it registers that a nurse has taken charge, the inte comes to life, chases the gurney, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Wait. I'm the doctor here! CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winnie paces, glances at the door that reads "Jim Rivera Director of Nursing” - 0.8. Denise is HEARD, "He choked..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIND RIVERA, his tense face pock-marked like the moon. Denise's voice is like the low growl of a doberman on a s leash.

dialogues.speaker: RIVERA
dialogues.text: -+-he was the doctor on call.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: He's an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: RIVERA
dialogues.text: You know the rules.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: The rules don't say I gotta wait for some moron to figure out which end of the stethoscope to use.

dialogues.speaker: RIVERA
dialogues.text: We're offering you a suspension. Without pay, of course.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: What a deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd take it if I were you. It could “ be worse.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Yeah. How?

dialogues.speaker: RIVERA
dialogues.text: The family of the dead boy isn't pressing charges. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: This stinks.

dialogues.speaker: RIVERA
dialogues.text: Off the record. You're right.

dialogues.speaker: . DENISE
dialogues.text: I'm not taking the suspension.

dialogues.speaker: RIVERA
dialogues.text: I didn't say it was a choice. f * A stand-off. i we

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Then I quit. cuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise scans the highway, brow furrowed. Across from her SAM, age ten. He knows she's worried.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Ma, how many psychiatrists does it take to change a light bulb?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: I give.

dialogues.speaker: . SAM
dialogues.text: None. The light bulb has gotta want to change itself. Get it? Denise looks at her son tenderly, wipes cherry filling fr his lips, plops a Celtics hat on his head.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I get it, smartypants. A_car horn HONKS in the b.g. Denise stiffens when she see MITCH, a swarthy Italian, waving from his muscle car. APR sits next to him. Barbie-doll pretty, all smiles. Sam jum up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Sam) Six o'clock. No excuses. GIL, the 50+ Italian donut shop owner, catches Sam.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: How 'bout a hug for your old uncle. Sam hugs Gil, kisses his mom, bolts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: {about April) That woman has more teeth than the winner of the Kentucky Derby. Denise starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: Denise, wait. Gil takes her hand, puts a wad of cash in it. Denise's ja tightens. Crying is out of the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the cash in Gil's shirt pocket, shakes her head, "no".

dialogues.speaker: GIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's an old man like me gonna do with extra cash?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Spend it on blondes? A look passes between them. Gil gently puts the cash back Denise's hands.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the only good man I know.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: And don't you forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pasty, over-weight PERSONNEL DIRECTOR skims her compute while chewing a milky way as if it were cud. Denise waits

dialogues.speaker: PERSONNEL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: I've got a position as temp nurse at Liberty Street.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: What is that..a shoe store?

dialogues.speaker: PERSONNEL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Convalescent. Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Forget it. Not my speed.

dialogues.speaker: PERSONNEL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: That's the best I can do, hot shot.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: (getting up) I'll get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: PERSONNEL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: With all the trauma centers closing-- I've got nothing in an ER. Denise looks dejected.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Look, I'd take the swing shift.

dialogues.speaker: PERSONNEL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: I have no openings, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PERSONNEL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: ++-come to think of it I do have something...a new hospital is recruiting...would you consider re- locating to Nova Scotia? Denise sinks lower in her chair. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise sits across the table from a blowzy blonde (MARION with a no-nonsense jaw, who shuffles through legal briefs

dialogues.speaker: MARION
dialogues.text: Taking a moral stand is admirable if you're Jesse Jackson. So, as your lawyer, I suggest...

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, I don't want to hear that Mitch has a chance...

dialogues.speaker: MARION
dialogues.text: With you out of work, you better believe it. He makes his support payments, sees Sam regularly...

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: He disappeared for three months with a bimbo.

dialogues.speaker: MARION
dialogues.text: A bimbo he's planning to marry. Frankly, I think he has a good chance of getting joint custody. You could have a worse guy for an ex.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe Charles Manson. Look, you don't get it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DENISE., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If he gets joint custody, it means he has a say in what Sam does; which means he has a say in what I do and there's no way in heli that slimy bastard is gonna control me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MARTON
dialogues.text: Still planning on moving to California with Sam?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: If I didn't have so many damn lawyer bills I'd be long gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARION
dialogues.text: Maybe you should've thought about that before you quit your job.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: (stung) You know what's brown and white and looks good on a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: MARION
dialogues.text: I've heard it. Get a job, Denise. Any job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: -+-yeah, this is Denise DeFiore. You know that job at that, what did you call it...Liberty Street?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. STREETS/DENISE'S CAR
dialogues.text: In her well-worn Ford escort, Denise passes a sign from t Massachusetts Historical Society that marks the entrance a township called "Danvers". Denise rushes past Cape Cods and federal houses heavy wit tradition. She checks the address of @ square, brick hous with a white picket fence. ivy climbs the front face of 1 Liberty Street from the ground to the widow's walk that c the hipped roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise knocks. After a few beats a black man in a three- Piece suit (CHARLIE), age indeterminate, answers.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You from the registry?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: That's me. Sorry I'm... CHARLIE . (about her uniform) You bring extra clothes?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That'll have to do. On Denise's quizzical look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it dips and bobs close on a COUPLE, mid-fifties. He is ruddy-faced and uncomfortable in a rented tux; she wears "mother-of-the-bride” polyester copy. She dabs her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +.-and on this occasion I am reminded of a verse in the Song of Solomon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The home video camera widens and swerves to reveal the co among the other guests. White satin, lots of doves and to tall floral arrangements thinly disguise the banquet room a wedding chapel. The video camera pans across the aisle the groom's PARENTS whose expressions are pinched.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "My beloved is mine and I am his, he pastures his flock among the lilies...until the day breathes and the shadows flee....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from the amateur camera person... A little BoY runs his Ninja Turtle up the shoulder of a l GIRL who's fallen asleep in het mother's lap...

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "...turn, my beloved, be like a gazelle, or a young stag upon rugged mountains.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: » Mt c€ oY, ll. Two WOMEN in their eighties sit beside a wheel-chair boun young woman (GRETCHEN) who wears horn-rimmed glasses. The wheel~chair is decorated with white satin ribbons and pin flowers. Behind Gretchen, a SOLDIER eyes a buxom REDHEAD across the aisle. His WIFE notices and elbows him sharply

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: +.-for loving someone is like holding sand... Denise stands at the back of the room beside an Ichabod- Crane looking man (MAX) who's in a wheelchair. Denise's l is distant.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: ++-close your hand tightly and. the sand drains away. Leave your hand open and the sand remains. The amateur camera person moves behind the minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the bride (ROSE) and the groom (BENJAMIN) gaze at one ano from matching wheelchairs. Both are crippled by cerebral Palsy. Ben takes Rose's withered hand in his.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ben, repeat after me. I Ben, take thee, Rose... Denise has had it. She slips out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise escapes into the claustrophobic hallway rancid wit smoke and earth-tone’ carpets. She pulls a cigarette from bag, lights up. In the b.g. a loud "NO" stops her action. young man (RICK) wearing a trench coat and fedora ‘a la B is mid~argument with Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No. No. I...I won't go.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Rick, I can't leave you alone. Denise stares. There's something wrong, but what? Rick is mid-twenties with the build of a running back. His face i boyishly handsome but there is something....disconnected. about him. Charlie gently tugs him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (too loud) No. You can't make me. You can't.
CHARLIE ; i Now what did we agree on, huh? & Rick clasps his hands to his ears, swings from side to si the gestures exaggerated, his reactions extreme.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I don't have to, I don't have to, I don't, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: / DENISE
dialogues.text: (sotto, to herself) Great. Loonies. I hate loonies. She starts to walk away. Hears a "hey you" but keeps walk Then a "Denise." She grimaces, busted.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Stay with Rick for me. And make sure he doesn't run off anywhere. Denise forces a resigned smile. Charlie ducks back into t ceremony. Rick looks Denise up and down, nothing subtle i his examination of her. Denise sense his desire to speak, but he can't engage his brain. He strains, searching for every word. When he speaks, his voice is thick and Slight monotone. Even so, Rick's eyes, when they connect, reveal natural intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You're, you're not Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Good call, Ace.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I'm not, not Ace. I'm Ricky. (in a deeper, "man's" voice) I mean, Rick. (a kid's voice again) And, and I'm not gonna talk until, until Kelly c..comes. Rick plops on the floor, cross-legged in protest.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Fine by me. (lights a cigarette) Wanta hear a joke? It's a good one. My kid told it to me. He's smart. (no answer) How many psychiatrists does it take to change a light bulb? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (no answer) None. The light bulb has gotta want to change itself. Rick stares at her, blankly.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got quite a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (about the cigarette) Those...those stink.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Hey, you wanta talk or you don't wanta talk, I don't care. But don't bust my chops. .

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: If you, you don't stop that, I'll run, run away.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Is that so. A stand-off. Rick scrambles to his feet, darts down the h Denise chases after him. She swears. He's fast.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Hey, hey gimme a break here.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Rick runs down the long hallway and out an emergency exit Sirens SCREECH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick covers his ears, screams along with the sirens. Deni catches him, tries to calm him down. Hotel personnel scur to the scene. Denise turns to see the wedding party and a of the guests spill into the Parking lot, dismayed. Charl glares at Denise.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Just a little misunderstanding. Everything's under control... cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise on the phone. In the b.g. she watches a poker game between Rick, Gretchen, Max and BRIDGET, a red-head with mild Downs. Rick wears his fedora.
Bridget arranges her cards for the eighth time, sings alo with the TV...the "Brady bunch, the Brady bunch... A bug- eyed, mildly crippled woman (JUSTINE) struggles, but mana to pull up a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Mitch, I'm gonna be a little late.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why doesn't Sam just stay over?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Because it's only a few minutes. {sotto, looking around) Look, nobody wants to get outta here tonight more than me.

dialogues.speaker: . MITCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You know we could avoid this lawyer thing...

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Oh, so you're givin' up?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No way. For Chrissakes what about Sam? We can give him more. April is home all day...

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: (keeping her voice down) April isn't his mother. I'll be home by eight. Be there. Denise paces absently half-watching the poker game. Rick deals, counts to himself. Max and Bridget sing the theme song, arrange their cards. Poker dialogue is HEARD..."Hit me. Hit me.”

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: (to Denise) ) Hey, you play poker?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GRETCHEN
dialogues.text: Grab a chair. (about Bridget) She needs a coach. Denise figures "what the hell", pulls up a chair next to "Red". Rick gives her a furtive glance. Denise hears a he LAUGH. DENISE'S Pov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc

Across the hall, the library of the old house is used as Administrator's office. LUCY ZACHARY has the title. She i mid-forties, a she~bear of a woman. She talks rapid-fire the phone, feet up on a cherry~wood desk. The front door opens and in blasts DEREK, early "20"'s, D Syndrome. He wears a "Chicken Lickin" Delivery Hat. He sl behind Justine, tickles her.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Tex, you she-devil. So how was the wedding? Ad lib answers. Derek eyes the cards. Looks at Rick, jeal apparent.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Rick) Hey, Bogie. Poker’s only five cards. You're so dense... Rick is red-faced, flustered. Ad-lib from the others..."l off, Derek..." Rick breathes heavily, stares at the table

dialogues.speaker: DEREK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, it's not my fault he's hopeless... A pause. Denise stares hard at Derek. She hates bullies.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: It's another game. He just forgot, the first two cards are down, the rest are up. It's called stud poker. Everyone reacts to the word "stud" as adolescents would. lib "oooh, Rick"... He smiles, vindicated. A look passes between Denise and Rick. A truce. Derek grimaces. Charlie appears, wearing an apron.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to the group) Do I look like Betty Crocker to you? You all get your butts in the kitchen. Help me get dinner, The game breaks up amid grumbling. Derek darts away with look that promises a future show down. Rick lage behind, approaches Denise. All is forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I...I like you... You're, you're pretty. Pretty.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Even if I'm not Kelly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ny

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: (a blank look) Kelly? {a distant memory) Oh yeah. You, you're prettier. (a pause) Well. Bye. He waves a wild "goodbye" on his to the kitchen. Denise doesn't know quite what to make of this odd man. A beat. Lucy enters, talking out loud.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What a day. Kelly's out for the duration with a complicated pregnancy and I'm out a nurse. (to Denise) Who're you? Denise's look says she's about to take advantage of this situation. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy clips down toward the kitchen. Denise half-jogs behi

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Do you. know what Freud wrote?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Freud? Lucy | "The final therapy is love and work." Denise looks rueful. What does that have to do with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise follows Lucy. Justine, Max, Gretchen help Charlie with dinner. Rick smiles at Denise. Watches her. She does notice. The others do. Lucy What's for dinner, Tex?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTINE
dialogues.text: Chili.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: iucy huffs and puffs. Denise is close behind.  17. r™ LUCY . " They take turns with the menu. Her Q chili could take the skin off a snake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Restored wallpaper and oak wainscoating. Denise and Lucy. Lucy Five bedrooms up, three down. Eight residents. Rose and Ben are our first married couple. You know the word, "Convalescent". It's supposed to mean, "become well again." Most of the time it translates as "waiting to die". Trust me, nobody waits at Liberty Street. For anything.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Good. .

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You bet it's good. And if anybody on the outside refers to this place as a “home” they answer to me. (points at the rooms) Gretchen's a librarian, sharp as a tack that one; Tex is a clerk, Max works for a publishing firm as an indexer. Everybody who lives here learns to go out in the world just like you and me.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Teach ‘em to join the rat race, huh. Sometimes I'm not so sure it's an advantage. Lucy You would if you couldn't do it. A pause. Denise considers the implications.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: What about that guy, Rick? Lucy He's new. We're still trying to place him in a job.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: rs He seems, I don't know...different. R f LUCY Lo Head trauma. Hit by a car when he was sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Jesus. Lucy Oh, he's on the road to recovery. {on her look) His memory's not great, he's easily frustrated and he's got a helluva temper but his IQ is well above normal. Physically, he's fine. Mentally, emotionally, that's something else. His mom's kept him at home much too isolated.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Will he ever be...uh... Lucy "Normal?" Whatever that is. (shaking her head)) Our toughest case. He's a grown man with the personality of a moody adolescent because his mother refuses to let go. Our job is to channel all that energy.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Rick's or his mother's?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Both. So. Why'd you quit the E.R.?

dialogues.text: Okay. This place is a far cry from meatball surgery.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Sounds good so far. Lucy The work is one on one, mostly tedious and very repetitive. There's no instant gratification, no adrenalin highs and I haven't saved a life since the cat choked on a fur ball.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Look, you need a nurse and I need a job. Do we have a deal or what?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Okay, you've got a shot. But don't think you can phone it in, Denise. Folks here aren't street-wise but, believe me, they're also not potted Plants. See you Monday.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: In a white-bread ghetto in a town called Peabody saved fr terminal despair by the dense New England foliage.
